content.description: Pull onto the face using sharp sidepulls and edges, and top out straight above. Using the right arete detracts from the climb and grade.
content.protection: Maybe a pad.
content.location: It is at the highest point on the hill directly between The Stacks and Magic Kingdom and will be on your right on the approach.

content.description: Establish yourself on the low angle face, and climb steepening terrain on small edges and crystals to the top.
content.protection: Pads. This is a bit of a tall one.
content.location: It is on the first slab boulder encountered along the trail below The Stacks.

content.description:
Pull the crux by getting situated on the slab above the small overlap about head high from the ground. Either continue direct through a juggy bulge (easy) or veer left onto the steeper face. Either finish with the final cracks on

Harry

or trend left and eventually crimp through crystals up the center of the final slab headwall. The small block in the corner to the left of the start is considered off.
content.protection: Sling a mammoth boulder on top for a TR.
content.location:
Start on the jutting overlap bulge just right (east) of the recessed corner which starts

The Hendersons

.

content.description: I struggled and somehow managed to climb this clean in sections with some hangdogging. Start with whatever you can find for a micro left hand, and grab the amazing arete with your right hand. Find believer moves once you pull on to the vertical face on nearly non-existent holds all the way to the cap rock. This has amazing, tenuous friction on great quality granite and is a wonderful feature in itself! This is a thin and technical testpiece and is an adventure just setting the TR.
content.protection: Scramble above the backside of the spire to the rocks adjacent to the spire's cap rock. Carefully step across, and do low 5th Class moves onto the top of the extremely exposed spire's small cap rock boulder, making sure you are solid reversing each move as climbing back is your only retreat from rigging the anchor. Use a long cordalette to sling deep under the backside of the caprock, hanging the masterpoint in a nice directional notch above the face.
content.location: It ascends ultra thin holds on the southwest face and uses the right arete.

content.description: Scramble to a couple easy parallel cracks and climb them to the headwall/crux alcove. Step up on the scary chockstone block and jam for a couple moves over the small bulge. The large tombstone like block is very hollow sounding, and it would be wise to not put outward force on it. It would earn the extra star if it weren't for a bit of debris here and there and the hollow block. This would be a great beginner lead on gear.
content.protection: It is a pretty easy solo for experienced moderate climbers. A few pieces of gear would be all that's needed at most. Plenty of anchor opportunities exist above.
content.location:
On the south side of The Stacks, locate a low angle and easy looking gully above and left from the belay area for

Harry

.

content.description: Start far left. Walk a heelhook all the way to the highest point of the lip, and mantel.
content.protection: A pad.
content.location:
It is on the large and obvious main boulder at the top of the drainage just a bit downhill from

The Hendersons

and

Elephant Shoulder

.

content.description: Climb directly up the face, and top out slightly left through a horn.
content.protection: A pad.
content.location:
It is just right of

Chutes

.

content.description: Start with clean layback hands working up to a jug on the face near the flared end of the crack.
content.protection: You could lead this with a piece of gear. A pad would not help this climb.
content.location:
It ascends the rightmost crack in the small nook directly right of

Locals Only

.

content.description: Climb the repeated horizontal cracks topping out in a small trough over the last small roof on the right side.
content.protection: It is easy to TR and there is an easy walkoff. It seems like it may be possible to lead on gear with some smaller pieces or perhaps initail runout.
content.location: It is on the first large wall low in The Stacks when hiking up to The Saddle.

content.description: Climb a right-angling, hand crack in a right-facing corner split by a good jug to another right angling hand crack, staying with it to the top.
content.protection: A few finger-hands pieces would be plenty. There are lots of boulders and trees to sling and easy walkoffs.
content.location:
This is right of

Harry

in a small recess in the rocks.

content.description: Start up a small, disconnected block below the small roof at 15'. Climb the slabby arete on the right until you reach the broken ledge covered with poo on your left. Traverse left, pull into the superb finger crack on the face, and climb it. This is a perfect finger crack with awesome exposure.
content.protection: A standard rack with some finger-size pieces and a 30' cordalette to sling a giant boulder for an anchor, if you choose.
content.location:
Head up the hillside south of The Stacks looking on your left for a small roof at about 15' with a splitter finger crack above. It is above and right (east) of

Littlefoot

.

content.description: Climb the wide crack past many "Happy Little Trees".
content.protection: Some hand-size cams may protect it. It was originally climbed free solo.
content.location:
It ascends the heavily vegetated wide crack to the right of

Harry

.

content.description: Pull into the small overlap, and climb up through the right-angling crack. Finish up the left side of the "Fridge" Block. Sling a huge block with cordalette for an anchor. Do an easy walkoff.
content.protection: A few mid to large cams could be used to lead it. It is easy to set a TR.
content.location: It is at the farthest end of The Stacks east from the road.

content.description: Pull the crux off the ground. Pull onto a small overhang/bulge, and finish with perfect holds and moves up the elephant trunk feature above. This is such a cool and uniquely exposed granite feature, albeit short.
content.protection: Bring long cord or rope to anchor the tree behind the elephant head, then use a cam or two in the cracks on top as a directional. Make sure to run your masterpoint over the face past the directional to avoid rope drag.
content.location:
Look for the elephant head at the top of the wall. The route starts on the vertical face to the right of the smooth slabs on '

Elephant Shoulder

' and follows the line up to and through the elephant trunk feature.

content.description: Elephant Shoulder is suprisingly clean, distinct, and technical. Climb to the first roof break, and pull the crux mantel onto the smooth slab. End standing atop the crux slab below the bush clogged gully above.
content.protection:
TR from the same tree as for

Elephantiasis

.
content.location:
It is immediately left of

Elephantiasis

. Start on the smooth pink slab.

content.description: Start as low as you prefer, and top out on jugs at the lip.
content.protection: Maybe a spotter for the rock behind.
content.location: On the same boulder on the northeast end past Lip Traverse V3.

content.description: Climb through flared hand jams to a wide exit.
content.protection: Maybe gear? A fall would be bad.
content.location:
It ascends the left crack in the inset area immediately right of

Locals Only

.

content.description: Climb up a solid hand crack, and jam to the right under and around the hanging boulder. Once above, step left, and tackle the short offwidth to the top.
content.protection: It could take gear up to a #5 or 6 if you wanted a piece for the offwidth up top. Originally, this was done free solo.
content.location:
Start right of

Harry

and

Happy Little Trees

in a corner. Step right over the bushes into the hand crack to start.

content.description: Step onto the block at the base, and follow the left-facing flakes to the top.
content.protection: A pad?
content.location:
Head right (north) around the corner from

The Fridge

to find this 15' wall with 2 lines.

content.description: Climb the vertical face on small holds. The anchor bolts seem a bit far up there, but the climb eases significantly here.
content.protection: 3 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor without rap rings. Clean and scramble off.
content.location:
This is the bolted line just left of

The Fridge

.
